45451.base_text: I woke up from a dreamless sleep to face the unpleasant truth that we couldn’t stay here forever.

variants.text: I woke up from a dreamless sleep to face the unpleasant truth that we couldn’t stay here forever.

45451.base_text: Hunger woke me, finally rising to the top of my list of needs.

variants.text: Hunger woke me, finally rising to the top of my list of needs.

45451.base_text: Getting back on top of the cylinder had been a problem of broken physics. We couldn’t just climb back up, because there was nothing heavy enough to grip. Maybe a master climber could have started from the bottom of a giant tube of carpet and made his way to the top, but even for Niko climbing had only ever been a fleeting hobby.

variants.text: Getting back on top of the cylinder had been a problem of broken physics. We couldn’t just climb back up, because there was nothing heavy enough to grip. Maybe a master climber could have started from the bottom of a giant tube of carpet and made his way to the top, but even for Niko climbing had only ever been a fleeting hobby.

45451.base_text: With Niko’s help I’d made it back to the top of the suspended bedroom set, as exhausted as I’d ever been. I thought nothing in the world had ever felt so good as lying on my back on a floor, every muscle gloriously unclenched. Wedged in between two dressers, so as not to roll off the edge, we slept.

variants.text: With Niko’s help I’d made it back to the top of the suspended bedroom set, as exhausted as I’d ever been. I thought nothing in the world had ever felt so good as lying on my back on a floor, every muscle gloriously unclenched. Wedged in between two dressers, so as not to roll off the edge, we slept.

45451.base_text: Getting back on top of the cylinder had been like navigating an especially surreal and challenging climbing gym. From his perch on the bookshelf, Niko had scoped out a route from one piece of furniture to the next, and then, in what would have been the most viral parkour video ever if YouTube had been invented yet, leapt from one to the other, till gasping, he scrabbled up to the top of the tube. From there he could pull me up; all I had to do with my shredded muscles was keep hanging on, although that was hard enough. Once we’d made it, I thought nothing in the world had ever felt so good as lying on my back on a floor, every muscle gloriously unclenched.

45451.base_text: With Niko’s help I’d made it back to the top of the suspended bedroom set, as exhausted as I’d ever been. I thought nothing in the world had ever felt so good as lying on my back on a floor, every muscle gloriously unclenched. Wedged in between two dressers, so as not to roll off the edge, we slept. His idea.

I’d managed to pull myself up to the top of the rope on the last of my shredded muscles and shove my arms into the gap between the bed and the floor, dangling by my armpits. Niko, farther up, worked out a plan. I wasn’t too coherent, but I gather he’d scoped out a route from one piece of furniture to the next, and then, in what would have been the most viral parkour video ever if YouTube had been invented yet, leapt from one to the other, pushing off each one as his weight lifted it off the ground, till gasping, he scrabbled up to the top of the tube.

45451.base_text: When we woke we ate power bars from Niko’s pack: my own had gotten lost somewhere in the fight, probably kicked off and down into the darkness below. I had no idea where to go from here, but Elder Niko’s plan still seemed sound: get across to a hallway on the other side. On the opposite wall of pink foam from the one we’d entered from, what seemed like ages ago, only one open hall was in reach of our floating set. It took some careful grapple work with our tired muscles, but in the end we managed to traverse over to the hallway, relieved to be standing on solid ground once again.

45451.base_text: When we woke we ate power bars from Niko’s pack: my own had gotten lost somewhere in the fight, probably kicked off and down into the darkness below. I had no idea where to go from here, but Niko had noticed something while scrambling around up top. One of the guy-wires sloping down into darkness had loops of rope tied to it every couple of feet, sized just right to be handholds. You could swing from one to the other, like monkey bars, working your way along and underneath. Unlike the guy-wires themselves which were coated in ages of grime, the loops of rope were clean. They looked like recent additions.

45451.base_text: From there it was simply a matter of making an anchor of a stack of fallen books, and flinging it around the tube to make a circular guide rope.

variants.text: From there it was simply a matter of making an anchor of a stack of fallen books, and flinging it around the tube to make a circular guide rope.

45451.base_text: This hallway had a floor of concrete, and was wider. A trench of water ran down its center, spilling out into the canyon behind us and cascading down.

variants.text: This hallway had a floor of concrete, and was wider. A trench of water ran down its center, spilling out into the canyon behind us and cascading down.

45451.base_text: From there it was simply a matter of detaching the chandelier net from its anchor point at the base of the hallway floating above us.

variants.text: From there it was simply a matter of detaching the chandelier net from its anchor point at the base of the hallway floating above us.

45451.base_text: A night’s rest had knitted our muscles back together enough to make the traversal merely painful rather than fatal. Grunting and moaning like old men, we swung away from the set into darkness, hand over hand.

variants.text: A night’s rest had knitted our muscles back together enough to make the traversal merely painful rather than fatal. Grunting and moaning like old men, we swung away from the set into darkness, hand over hand.

45451.base_text: Wedged in between two dressers, so as not to roll off the edge, we slept.

variants.text: Wedged in between two dressers, so as not to roll off the edge, we slept.

45451.base_text: I had to rest for a while before I felt confident enough to make the climb around. But it was only thirty feet, and only a small part of that vertical. Before I could overthink it I’d done it and was back on top. I thought nothing in the world had ever felt so good as lying on my back on a floor, every muscle gloriously unclenched.

Before I could overthink it I’d done it and was back on top. I thought nothing in the world had ever felt so good as lying on my back on a floor, every muscle gloriously unclenched.

45451.base_text: I never would have thought of this. But Niko figured all those glass baubles together ought to weigh more than we did. That the chandelier-web, part of the Confusion, should follow its own gravitational rules, not the ones that dragged us downwards. Like a cloth thrown over a crystal ball, the detached net would wrap around the curvature of the bedroom tube, with both of us inside but not heavy enough to pull it free. We’d be able to crawl back around to the top, ants between the cloth and the glass.

45451.base_text: Before long our headlamps picked out a looming shape ahead: a huge concrete tube snaking horizontal through the blackness and cutting across our path on a diagonal. The wire ran just above it, so when we reached it we could simply step down onto its curving top side to shake out our weary arms.

The wire ran just above it, so when we reached it we could simply step down onto its curving top side to shake out our weary arms.

45451.base_text: When we woke we ate power bars from Niko’s pack: my own had gotten lost somewhere in the fight, probably sliding off the curve and down into the darkness below. I had no idea where to go from here—although it seemed like there were only two options, one way down the tube or the other—but Niko had found a better option while he’d been scrambling around up top. Directly under the invisible anchor point of the densest part of the web, the chandelier itself, was a trapdoor. It opened downward with a creak when you pushed on it, releasing fold-up stairs like the ones that sometimes climb into attics. The stairs descended some fifteen feet to a cement floor bisecting the cylinder. Its upper half was a domed tunnel, vanishing into the distance in either direction. Bare bulbs hung from the roof every fifty feet or so, leaking dim puddles of yellow-orange glow. Water ran down the center in a foot-deep trench, fast enough to gurgle.

45451.base_text: It worked. There must have been some complicated gymnastics up there, and I’m fuzzy on how he got the net loose—maybe he had his own serrated knife—but it worked. Back on top, the net of glass now a glittering ceiling over the bedroom furniture like the world’s most fabulous couch fort, I thought nothing in the world had ever felt so good as lying on my back on a floor, every muscle gloriously unclenched.

45451.base_text: We kept to the level ground on either side of the trench, and started trudging.

variants.text: We kept to the level ground on either side of the trench, and started trudging.

45451.base_text: Niko thought we should head upstream, follow the water toward its source. Too worn down to argue, I agreed.

variants.text: Niko thought we should head upstream, follow the water toward its source. Too worn down to argue, I agreed.

45451.base_text: We moved slowly. Niko had cleaned up the cut in my lower leg as best he could, bandaging it with some socks from a dresser drawer and a tight-wrapped bungee cord from his pack. But it hurt, a lot. I hobbled more than walked, had to stop for frequent breaks, or lean on him for support. He helped me without comment, when I needed it.

45451.base_text: I couldn’t help notice, up close to him like that, that he seemed to have all his fingers.

45451.base_text: Unsaid things festered between us.

There were no side doors, no junctions, no rooms. There were no decisions to make. We just walked. Other than an occasional grunt or word of coordination, we didn’t speak. A small part of me wanted to ask a million questions. Another part didn’t want the answers. There was a tautness between us, a strain, like a handshake stripped down to bone and gristle, rubbing, raw. I realized maybe it had been there a long time, underneath everything we’d wrapped around it.

45451.base_text: The tunnel had no perceptible slope, but the water in the trench ran fast, rushing eagerly past us. The path stayed straight at first but then began to curve gently leftward. We walked for what felt like a long time.

variants.text: The tunnel had no perceptible slope, but the water in the trench ran fast, rushing eagerly past us. The path stayed straight at first but then began to curve gently leftward. We walked for what felt like a long time.

45451.base_text: The tunnel had no perceptible slope, but the water in the trench ran fast, rushing eagerly past us. The path curved gently left, then gently right. We walked for what felt like a long time.

variants.text: The tunnel had no perceptible slope, but the water in the trench ran fast, rushing eagerly past us. The path curved gently left, then gently right. We walked for what felt like a long time.

45451.base_text: Gradually, the perfect curve of the ceiling began to straighten. The roof above flattened, the curves at its edge sharpening, until they squared off entirely. At the same time the tunnel gradually shrunk back to house-sized dimensions. Presently we were walking down a rectangular hall of concrete, like some forgotten subbasement in a shuttered factory. It felt like we were back “inside” again. The sensation of walking through a pipe suspended over empty space receded, and we felt once again embedded in earth.

It was a squat and vaulted brick antechamber, maybe twelve feet across and hexagonal, with tunnels coming in from all six sides. Each seemed identical to the one we’d entered from. Water flooded the sunken floor of the chamber and ran out the trenches in the middle of each tunnel.

45451.base_text: There was so much I should be asking him, so much I should be saying, but I couldn’t find a way to start.

45451.base_text: Well. I had pretended nothing was wrong for such a long time. Maybe another few minutes wouldn’t hurt.

variants.text: Well. I had pretended nothing was wrong for such a long time. Maybe another few minutes wouldn’t hurt.

45451.base_text: The rippling sounds of the water were peaceful, and I didn’t want to break the silence. But someone had to.

variants.text: The rippling sounds of the water were peaceful, and I didn’t want to break the silence. But someone had to.

45451.base_text: “So.” The sound bounced off vaulted brick, making the chamber even more claustrophobic. I coughed. “We’ve come all this way. We going through, or what?”

45451.base_text: He seemed curiously reluctant, but managed a weak smile. “Sure! Yeah. Let’s do it.”

variants.text: He seemed curiously reluctant, but managed a weak smile. “Sure! Yeah. Let’s do it.”

45451.base_text: We waded over to the hatchway. The wheel was inches under the surface of the water. I pulled the key from my pocket and slipped it into the lock, and it went in smoothly. I spun it through a full turn till it made a tiny chunk, then turned the wheel. After a few revolutions, something gave, and we found we could swing the circular hatch open along one hinged side.

45451.base_text: The words seemed to shake him out of a daze, and he perked up, flashing a huge grin. “Hell yeah! Let’s do it. Let’s go home.”

variants.text: The words seemed to shake him out of a daze, and he perked up, flashing a huge grin. “Hell yeah! Let’s do it. Let’s go home.”

45451.base_text: We held our glowsticks underwater near the opening. The hatch opened into an ordinary-looking but flooded room beneath us with a yellow-tiled floor. Chrome and porcelain rippled up at us. We realized after a moment it was a flooded bathroom.

45451.base_text: “If this portal thing leads through a toilet,” Niko said, “I’m out.”

variants.text: “If this portal thing leads through a toilet,” Niko said, “I’m out.”

45451.base_text: We could only assume the way through was somewhere out of sight, around a corner or down an unseen hall. But how far?

variants.text: We could only assume the way through was somewhere out of sight, around a corner or down an unseen hall. But how far?

45451.base_text: “The other guys are probably doing the same thing on their side,” I said hopefully. “Maybe we’ll swim through at exactly the same time, go past each other.”

45451.base_text: “Huh.” I looked over; he was staring uneasily into the flooded opening. He caught me looking and forced a smile. “Why not, right? Makes as much sense as anything else.” But his gaze slipped off me and up to the vaulted ceiling, like he was interested in the architecture. He wasn’t.

45451.base_text: “You really think we’re still in sync? After everything that’s happened? Our doubles defeated their own evil Niko with exactly the same strategy and ended up here at precisely the same time as us?”

variants.text: “You really think we’re still in sync? After everything that’s happened? Our doubles defeated their own evil Niko with exactly the same strategy and ended up here at precisely the same time as us?”

45451.base_text: He was worried about something.

I turned away, ignoring the upwelling of unease, and frowned at the hatch. There was something familiar inside it. I squinted, trying to make the wavering underwater shapes resolve. Tied to something just under the hatchway was a climbing rope, the same kind we’d used with our Grip Monkeys. It stretched down in a taut line out of sight, towards the hidden wall of the room beneath us.

45451.base_text: He shrugged. “Might as well believe that. Because if we don’t, and, uh, there’s no way back… that would kind of suck.”

45451.base_text: “We don’t even know if this goes anywhere,” I said. “For all we know, there’s a mile of flooded tunnel down there before it mirrors back to our world, if it ever does. You know what would suck more? Drowning.”

45451.base_text: “And this goes through to another hatch like this one, you think? One that opens up onto our original side?”

variants.text: “And this goes through to another hatch like this one, you think? One that opens up onto our original side?”

45451.base_text: “What are you doing?” I asked, unsettled.

variants.text: “What are you doing?” I asked, unsettled.

45451.base_text: He nodded, still not looking at me. “What my evil twin was looking for. The way back through. And if we’re lucky, our doubles will be waiting on the other side. Just like this. Getting ready to swap places, swim through. Get everyone back where they belong, all neat and tidy.”

45451.base_text: “No time like the present,” he said. “Might as well get it over with. Come on in, the water’s fine.”

variants.text: “No time like the present,” he said. “Might as well get it over with. Come on in, the water’s fine.”

45451.base_text: “And, uh. You know this how?” I swallowed. Here was the discussion I’d been too afraid to start, happening anyway.

variants.text: “And, uh. You know this how?” I swallowed. Here was the discussion I’d been too afraid to start, happening anyway.

45451.base_text: Something was wrong again. The dark circle of the submerged porthole was ominous. Unknown. This was happening way too fast. “I don’t know. Shit. What if something happens down there? What if one of us gets stuck, or needs help? We could fucking drown.” My mind was racing. It felt like riding a bike that kept slipping gears, nothing quite fitting together, accelerating down a hill with less and less control, no way to stop.

But we might as well believe it, because if they’re not there, and there’s no more synchronicity between us at all any more? Then who the fuck knows where this rope leads.” He shook his head. “No. They’re over there. We have to believe that. They’re having this same discussion, right now.”

45451.base_text: “Let’s just do it,” Niko said brightly. “I mean, the sooner we go through, the sooner we’ll be home.”

45451.base_text: “They.”

“How did you even know this was here?” My throat tightened. His eyes widened. “No. I can’t do this again. Why won’t any of you be honest with me? Stop it. I know. I know. You’re not… you’re not really…”

45451.base_text: My voice broke and he looked up startled, guilty, afraid. Like a texting jaywalker realizing too late he’s wandered into traffic.

variants.text: My voice broke and he looked up startled, guilty, afraid. Like a texting jaywalker realizing too late he’s wandered into traffic.

45451.base_text: Somewhere far below us, something groaned, low, immense. The ground quivered, like a mountain turning over in its sleep, and the surface of the water pinched and jittered in sympathy. And just as this happened Niko reached up, eyes wide, and touched two fingers to my lips. Made a zipping motion across them. I was shocked into silence by it all: the sound, the absurdity of the gesture, his fingers on my lips. The fear on his face.

45451.base_text: “Niko,” I said, trembling. “Are you sure you’re… I mean, when we got separated…”

45451.base_text: “Don’t,” he said, quiet. “Please.”

Somewhere far below us, something groaned, low, immense. The ground quivered, like a mountain turning over in its sleep, and the surface of the water pinched and jittered in sympathy. We both dropped half into a crouch, but the earthquake stopped, the low rumbles far beneath us faded. The water we stood in sloshed drunkenly.

“It’s the only way.” He gazed at me, fierce. “Orion, just trust me, okay? This will all work out, but you need to trust me right now. Can you do that?”

45451.base_text: His lips were too close to mine. It would be so easy. What I’d always wanted made real, at last.

45451.base_text: “I want to,” I breathed.
He let go of me, took a step back, face reddening. “I just think,” he said quietly, miserable, “that you should go first, okay?”

variants.text: He let go of me, took a step back, face reddening. “I just think,” he said quietly, miserable, “that you should go first, okay?”

45451.base_text: A sharp crack sounded from the wall behind him, but I refused to look away from his eyes, even though all I saw reflected there was my own pain, bitter and jagged.

variants.text: A sharp crack sounded from the wall behind him, but I refused to look away from his eyes, even though all I saw reflected there was my own pain, bitter and jagged.

45451.base_text: “Then do it.” The need in his eyes was almost too bright to bear.

variants.text: “Then do it.” The need in his eyes was almost too bright to bear.

45451.base_text: The walls around us crunched, coughed, like millions of brick bones having chiropractic work done.

variants.text: The walls around us crunched, coughed, like millions of brick bones having chiropractic work done.

45451.base_text: “And when your double swims through,” he said, lips tight. “The one who belongs on this side. What’ll we do with him? Will we kill him, too?”

variants.text: “And when your double swims through,” he said, lips tight. “The one who belongs on this side. What’ll we do with him? Will we kill him, too?”

45451.base_text: I shook my head. “Not that. I want to trust you.”

variants.text: I shook my head. “Not that. I want to trust you.”

45451.base_text: Maybe it was my imagination, but the room seemed smaller.

variants.text: Maybe it was my imagination, but the room seemed smaller.

45451.base_text: “Yes,” I said.
He blinked. “Then do that.” But I pulled back, biting my lip, and his brow creased with worry. “Can’t you?”

variants.text: He blinked. “Then do that.” But I pulled back, biting my lip, and his brow creased with worry. “Can’t you?”

45451.base_text: And then something else hit me. Something so hard and huge I forgot how to breathe, and staggered back away from it.

variants.text: And then something else hit me. Something so hard and huge I forgot how to breathe, and staggered back away from it.

45451.base_text: The ground dropped out from under us, like a plane hitting turbulence. Rumbles quivered in stone far below. I felt a rush of power. I felt filled with potency. Charged. I could bring this whole place down if I wanted. I could change everything.

variants.text: The ground dropped out from under us, like a plane hitting turbulence. Rumbles quivered in stone far below. I felt a rush of power. I felt filled with potency. Charged. I could bring this whole place down if I wanted. I could change everything.

45451.base_text: I wanted to laugh. Trust? Could we trust each other? The question unraveled into a million strands, tendrils stretching back through everything that had happened down here, and everything that had happened before that. Trust. What a beautiful, fucked-up, irrational concept.

45451.base_text: I let you swim through first. Can’t remember. Why.

45451.base_text: “Orion,” Niko shouted over the noise, staggering on the unsteady ground. “Stop this. You don’t belong here. You have to go back.”

variants.text: “Orion,” Niko shouted over the noise, staggering on the unsteady ground. “Stop this. You don’t belong here. You have to go back.”

45451.base_text: He kept his gaze locked on mine.

variants.text: He kept his gaze locked on mine.

45451.base_text: I tried to see him. Really see him. I willed the layers of muck and confusion between us to pull back, to clear away and reveal someone, at last, who I could understand. The Niko who forgave me. The Niko I’d hurt. The Nikos I’d saved, damned, slept with; the ones who needed me, who hated me, who wanted me dead. The one I’d tried so hard to find, looked everywhere for, down here, up there, inside us both and beyond possibility. Each of them were tales disguised as truths; worlds that I yearned to slip into like tailored gloves, sized just right; stories reassuring me that I finally understood what I deserved, good or bad, where I belonged and who I belonged to, and who belonged to me, where I didn’t have to be afraid that I’d love the wrong person or the wrong person would love me.

45451.base_text: “There’s nothing for me there.” But the momentary flicker of power drained away as I realized I couldn’t convince him, could change the architecture as much as I wanted but could never change him, could never accomplish anything from trying but killing us both. I kept my eyes locked on his, refused to blink, afraid he’d be someone else if I did, another Niko, another Bradley. “I belong with you,” I cried, “here. I can’t go back there. I’d be alone. Don’t leave me alone.”

45451.base_text: Couldn’t find my way. Back up.
The surface of the water twitched, rippled. Waiting.

45451.base_text: He froze, face draining of color, and as he did the noise stopped too. The rumbles, the distant groans and tremors, were gone. The quiet thrummed in our ears. I didn’t understand.

45451.base_text: But people don’t wrap up like that into nice little cages, contained. We weren’t each others’ stories. He wasn’t the Niko I wanted. None of them had been, even if this one thought maybe he could be, was as deluded as I’d been. We’d mistaken shadows for substance, all of us: chased them and failed, of course, to grab them, become shadows ourselves in failing.

45451.base_text: He was reaching for me but I tripped backwards, reflecting his concern with horror. No. No, no, no. As each brick popped others surged into the gaps they made. The walls were squeezing closer. The room was barely nine feet across, now. Water surged into the runnels leading out, cascading away in all directions like it, too, was terrified.

45451.base_text: And then I remembered.

“It’s okay,” Niko was saying, smiling through the tears. But it wasn’t. He hadn’t been close enough to hear what his elder had been whispering. He didn’t know. “If it doesn’t work I’ll just stay on this side, retrace our route. No biggie. Get back to the top and so what if there’s some headaches. I’ll deal.”

45451.base_text: Don’t leave me alone. It was what he’d said to me, the night of his accident. His mistake. After I’d stopped him from making it. Before the one we made together and had never made right.

45451.base_text: “I’m going through.” I took a deep breath. “But it’s not because I trust you.” He looked alarmed but I raised a hand. “It’s okay. Let me finish. I don’t deserve your trust, and maybe I don’t know how to give it to anyone else. But if I have to start somewhere I should start with myself. And I think I can do this. I trust I can. Okay? I made Tiger Shark in swim club and I can hold my breath for three minutes and I can make it. I can make it through. I can. But Niko, you can’t come with me.” Tears sprung like pinpricks to my eyes, but I blinked them back, fierce. “You can’t come with me.”

45451.base_text: I took a deep breath. “Maybe synchronicity matters, maybe it doesn’t. I don’t really give a shit. What I want is to get us both back home. Look, I don’t deserve your trust, and maybe I don’t know how to give it to anyone else. But if I have to start somewhere I should start with myself. And I think I can do this. I trust I can. Okay? I made Tiger Shark in swim club and I can hold my breath for three minutes and I can make it. I can make it through. I can. And you are fucking coming with me, because I may be the reason you’re down here but I swear to god I will also be the reason you get back out.”

45451.base_text: The words lingered in the air. We stayed suspended for a moment, unable to break eye contact, afraid, maybe, to look at anything but each other.

variants.text: The words lingered in the air. We stayed suspended for a moment, unable to break eye contact, afraid, maybe, to look at anything but each other.

45451.base_text: I took a long, ragged breath and realized what I’d said was true. And not just for him.

variants.text: I took a long, ragged breath and realized what I’d said was true. And not just for him.

45451.base_text: A single brick tumbled from the ceiling and made a tremendous splash. We both started, then laughed, and couldn’t stop laughing. We were buried alive and almost certainly going to die but goddamn, we were going to do it together.

45451.base_text: “I know,” I said again, “I’ll do it. I’ll go back. I’ll swim through. But not because I trust you.” He looked up, alarmed, but I raised a hand. “I don’t deserve your trust, and maybe I don’t know how to give it to anyone else. But if I have to start somewhere I should start with myself. And I think I can do this. I trust I can. Okay? I made Tiger Shark in swim club and I can hold my breath for three minutes and I can make it. I can make it through. I can.”

45451.base_text: He broke our gaze. His eyes fell to the water beneath us like he’d dropped something, watched resigned as it sunk away for good, no longer trying to save it.

45451.base_text: “Yeah.” He took a breath, then another. “Yeah, okay. We’ll try it your way. You win. This time, dipshit.”

45451.base_text: I didn’t believe it, not really. But saying the words was a good start.

variants.text: I didn’t believe it, not really. But saying the words was a good start.

45451.base_text: “Guess, from your perspective,” he said carefully, “that should have been my line.”

variants.text: “Guess, from your perspective,” he said carefully, “that should have been my line.”

45451.base_text: It was decided. It felt good, and yet painful, too, as some pinprick of knowledge stabbed into me, saying even if we did survive, nothing would ever be the same between us. So without overthinking it I stepped forward and hugged him, fierce as the roiling lump in my throat.

45451.base_text: “Sorry I fucked everything up,” I added.

variants.text: “Sorry I fucked everything up,” I added.

45451.base_text: “Yeah, well.” I waved my hand at the architecture around us. “Life’s got a funny way of fucking everything up.”

variants.text: “Yeah, well.” I waved my hand at the architecture around us. “Life’s got a funny way of fucking everything up.”

45451.base_text: “Yeah, bit late for that.” He waved a hand. “Whatever. Tsunami under the bridge. Apology accepted, I mean.”

45451.base_text: He laughed, sudden and loud, and even if things weren’t right, even if the edge between us was jagged and always would be, it was good to hear that laugh again.

variants.text: He laughed, sudden and loud, and even if things weren’t right, even if the edge between us was jagged and always would be, it was good to hear that laugh again.

45451.base_text: We breathed. It was settled.

“So,” he said. “You’ll swim through. Pass your other.” He swallowed; I nodded. Just my other. Not his. “And then we’ll each be where we should be.” His face hardened into a mask as he said this, grim and colorless. Then he looked at me, the corner of his mouth twisting in pain but also a challenge, flinging some of the pain back: “You’ll be fine without me, I guess. Yeah?”

Not his. “And then we’ll each be where we should be.” I noticed he didn’t say “where we belong” and silently thanked him for that. Belonging was just another kind of longing, I thought, equally stupid to yearn for, to think you could only get from somebody else.

45451.base_text: I turned away, toward the submerged portal, the way out, the way home. I stared down at it.

45451.base_text: I stripped down to my jeans, self-conscious, but Niko was spinning a theory about the identical set of clothes I’d find on the other side. If alter-me was swimming through too, he should have had this same thought, and we’d both have dry shirts and shoes waiting, and wasn’t that cool?

45451.base_text: His bare skin, still damp, felt hot against my own. He held me tight, wet curls rubbing against my face. Heat passed between us, but it was the least of what had.

45451.base_text: I wasn’t really processing this, still overwhelmed. Trust. Pairs of universes, pulling apart. Drowning, death. Dry clothes seemed like insubstantial details. I tied the glow stick to my belt loop, emptied my pockets of everything non-essential.

For a second it looked like he thought I was going to kiss him, and then I thought maybe he was thinking of kissing me, out of some kind of misplaced solidarity, and we both stood uncertain for a second or two before dropping arms and stepping back.

45451.base_text: Almost on autopilot I guided Niko through what to expect, through breathing exercises, stroke technique. Calming him down as much as myself. Preparing.

45451.base_text: “Oh hey,” he said as I did this, affecting it as a casual afterthought, “I want you to take something through for me.” He pulled a plastic bag from his pocket, folded-up pages with something written on them inside. “Hold onto it for a while, okay? Just till you get back through.”

45451.base_text: “Sure.” I took the bag. “I suppose I shouldn’t read it until—?” A faint judder rippled through the ground; for an instant the water danced in interference patterns.

45451.base_text: He looked pained. “Please, please don’t.” Glancing around, he took a deep breath. “Okay. You ready?”

45451.base_text: “Last one back to the right dimension buys the drinks,” I said, then took one last huge breath and dove headfirst into the hatch.

45451.base_text: The thought of swimming into that hole without knowing the way to the other side stabbed a different part of me, the one concerned with oxygen and continued existence. I pushed the fear down but it kept manufacturing images for me: jeans snagging on hidden nails that held me back while I flailed uselessly; huge dead fish swimming the flooded halls with flaking gray skin, bulging eyes growing larger and larger as they closed on me. I imagined drowning. Breathing water instead of air. Spasms of lungs. Knowing you were about to die, only not soon enough. Not nearly soon enough.

45451.base_text: “Are you going to be okay?” he asked.

45451.base_text: “Are you going to be okay?” he asked, without spite this time.

45451.base_text: I didn’t know how to answer, because despite these tidy revelations, the thought of never seeing him again still stabbed at something deep inside me, and maybe always would; and the idea that anyone in this or any world would ever know me as well as he did seemed impossible. But I nodded. Eventually, maybe, it would be true.

45451.base_text: I stared at the circular opening, visualized the motions I’d make. I tried to believe I could do this. I tried to push down the sliver of doubt lodged somewhere in my throat.

45451.base_text: “How about you?”
Gripping the sides of the hatch, I paused. I wasn’t ready. But if I waited any longer, I’d never be.

45451.base_text: He grinned. “I don’t plan to spend a couple decades sulking down here like that asshole, if that’s what you mean.” He looked up at the arched roof above us, scanning the bricks like there might be constellations in them. “I’ve never known what I wanted, man. Just what everybody else wants me to want. I’m sorry I mixed you up in all that.” He shrugged. “Guess I should figure that out, yeah? Spend some time with myself. Maybe more solo camping, you know? Wandering in the wilderness. Worked for Jesus.”

45451.base_text: “Sure,” I said. “You see that wolf again up there, man… you fucking wreck it.”

45451.base_text: I took a deep breath, then another. I tried to slow my heartbeat. I didn’t look at Niko.

45451.base_text: Another breath. Breathe. Deeper and deeper.
“Later, skater,” I said, not looking back, then took one last huge breath and dove headfirst into the hatch.

45452.base_text: I woke up from a dreamless sleep to face the unpleasant truth that we couldn’t stay here forever.

45452.base_text: Hunger woke me, finally rising to the top of my list of needs.

45452.base_text: Getting back on top of the cylinder had been a problem of broken physics. We couldn’t just climb back up, because there was nothing heavy enough to grip. Maybe a master climber could have started from the bottom of a giant tube of carpet and made his way to the top, but even for Niko climbing had only ever been a fleeting hobby.

45452.base_text: With Niko’s help I’d made it back to the top of the suspended bedroom set, as exhausted as I’d ever been. I thought nothing in the world had ever felt so good as lying on my back on a floor, every muscle gloriously unclenched. Wedged in between two dressers, so as not to roll off the edge, we slept.

45452.base_text: Getting back on top of the cylinder had been like navigating an especially surreal and challenging climbing gym. From his perch on the bookshelf, Niko had scoped out a route from one piece of furniture to the next, and then, in what would have been the most viral parkour video ever if YouTube had been invented yet, leapt from one to the other, till gasping, he scrabbled up to the top of the tube. From there he could pull me up; all I had to do with my shredded muscles was keep hanging on, although that was hard enough. Once we’d made it, I thought nothing in the world had ever felt so good as lying on my back on a floor, every muscle gloriously unclenched.

His idea.

I’d managed to pull myself up to the top of the rope on the last of my shredded muscles and shove my arms into the gap between the bed and the floor, dangling by my armpits. Niko, farther up, worked out a plan. I wasn’t too coherent, but I gather he’d scoped out a route from one piece of furniture to the next, and then, in what would have been the most viral parkour video ever if YouTube had been invented yet, leapt from one to the other, pushing off each one as his weight lifted it off the ground, till gasping, he scrabbled up to the top of the tube.

45452.base_text: When we woke we ate power bars from Niko’s pack: my own had gotten lost somewhere in the fight, probably kicked off and down into the darkness below. I had no idea where to go from here, but Elder Niko’s plan still seemed sound: get across to a hallway on the other side. On the opposite wall of pink foam from the one we’d entered from, what seemed like ages ago, only one open hall was in reach of our floating set. It took some careful grapple work with our tired muscles, but in the end we managed to traverse over to the hallway, relieved to be standing on solid ground once again.

45452.base_text: When we woke we ate power bars from Niko’s pack: my own had gotten lost somewhere in the fight, probably kicked off and down into the darkness below. I had no idea where to go from here, but Niko had noticed something while scrambling around up top. One of the guy-wires sloping down into darkness had loops of rope tied to it every couple of feet, sized just right to be handholds. You could swing from one to the other, like monkey bars, working your way along and underneath. Unlike the guy-wires themselves which were coated in ages of grime, the loops of rope were clean. They looked like recent additions.

45452.base_text: From there it was simply a matter of making an anchor of a stack of fallen books, and flinging it around the tube to make a circular guide rope.

45452.base_text: This hallway had a floor of concrete, and was wider. A trench of water ran down its center, spilling out into the canyon behind us and cascading down.

45452.base_text: From there it was simply a matter of detaching the chandelier net from its anchor point at the base of the hallway floating above us.

45452.base_text: A night’s rest had knitted our muscles back together enough to make the traversal merely painful rather than fatal. Grunting and moaning like old men, we swung away from the set into darkness, hand over hand.

45452.base_text: I had to rest for a while before I felt confident enough to make the climb around. But it was only thirty feet, and only a small part of that vertical. Before I could overthink it I’d done it and was back on top. I thought nothing in the world had ever felt so good as lying on my back on a floor, every muscle gloriously unclenched.

45452.base_text: I never would have thought of this. But Niko figured all those glass baubles together ought to weigh more than we did. That the chandelier-web, part of the Confusion, should follow its own gravitational rules, not the ones that dragged us downwards. Like a cloth thrown over a crystal ball, the detached net would wrap around the curvature of the bedroom tube, with both of us inside but not heavy enough to pull it free. We’d be able to crawl back around to the top, ants between the cloth and the glass.

45452.base_text: Before long our headlamps picked out a looming shape ahead: a huge concrete tube snaking horizontal through the blackness and cutting across our path on a diagonal. The wire ran just above it, so when we reached it we could simply step down onto its curving top side to shake out our weary arms.

45452.base_text: When we woke we ate power bars from Niko’s pack: my own had gotten lost somewhere in the fight, probably sliding off the curve and down into the darkness below. I had no idea where to go from here—although it seemed like there were only two options, one way down the tube or the other—but Niko had found a better option while he’d been scrambling around up top. Directly under the invisible anchor point of the densest part of the web, the chandelier itself, was a trapdoor. It opened downward with a creak when you pushed on it, releasing fold-up stairs like the ones that sometimes climb into attics. The stairs descended some fifteen feet to a cement floor bisecting the cylinder. Its upper half was a domed tunnel, vanishing into the distance in either direction. Bare bulbs hung from the roof every fifty feet or so, leaking dim puddles of yellow-orange glow. Water ran down the center in a foot-deep trench, fast enough to gurgle.

45452.base_text: It worked. There must have been some complicated gymnastics up there, and I’m fuzzy on how he got the net loose—maybe he had his own serrated knife—but it worked. Back on top, the net of glass now a glittering ceiling over the bedroom furniture like the world’s most fabulous couch fort, I thought nothing in the world had ever felt so good as lying on my back on a floor, every muscle gloriously unclenched.

45452.base_text: Wedged in between two dressers, so as not to roll off the edge, we slept. His idea.

45452.base_text: When we woke we ate power bars from Niko’s pack: my own had gotten lost somewhere in the fight, probably sliding off the curve and down into the darkness below. I had no idea where to go from here—although it seemed like there were only two options, one way down the tube or the other—but Niko had found a better option while he’d been scrambling around up top. Directly at the foot of the bookshelf, whose fractal overspill had all collapsed and fallen into darkness, was a trapdoor. It opened downward with a creak when you pushed on it, releasing fold-up stairs like the ones that sometimes climb into attics. 45452.base_text: We kept to the level ground on either side of the trench, and started trudging.

45452.base_text: Niko thought we should head upstream, follow the water toward its source. Too worn down to argue, I agreed.

variants.text: Niko thought we should head upstream, follow the water toward its source. Too worn down to argue, I agreed.

45452.base_text: We moved slowly. Niko had cleaned up the cut in my lower leg as best he could, bandaging it with some socks from a dresser drawer and a tight-wrapped bungee cord from his pack. But it hurt, a lot. I hobbled more than walked, had to stop for frequent breaks, or lean on him for support. He helped me without comment, when I needed it.

45452.base_text: Unsaid things festered between us.

There were no side doors, no junctions, no rooms. There were no decisions to make. We just walked. Other than an occasional grunt or word of coordination, we didn’t speak. A small part of me wanted to ask a million questions. Another part didn’t want the answers. There was a tautness between us, a strain, like a handshake stripped down to bone and gristle, rubbing, raw. I realized maybe it had been there a long time, underneath everything we’d wrapped around it.

45452.base_text: The tunnel had no perceptible slope, but the water in the trench ran fast, rushing eagerly past us. The path stayed straight at first but then began to curve gently leftward. We walked for what felt like a long time.

45452.base_text: The tunnel had no perceptible slope, but the water in the trench ran fast, rushing eagerly past us. The path curved gently left, then gently right. We walked for what felt like a long time.

variants.text: The tunnel had no perceptible slope, but the water in the trench ran fast, rushing eagerly past us. The path curved gently left, then gently right. We walked for what felt like a long time.

45452.base_text: Gradually, the perfect curve of the ceiling began to straighten. The roof above flattened, the curves at its edge sharpening, until they squared off entirely. At the same time the tunnel gradually shrunk back to house-sized dimensions. Presently we were walking down a rectangular hall of concrete, like some forgotten subbasement in a shuttered factory. It felt like we were back “inside” again. The sensation of walking through a pipe suspended over empty space receded, and we felt once again embedded in earth.

It was a squat and vaulted brick antechamber, maybe twelve feet across and hexagonal, with tunnels coming in from all six sides. Each seemed identical to the one we’d entered from. Water flooded the sunken floor of the chamber and ran out the trenches in the middle of each tunnel.

45452.base_text: Once we confirmed it did, we became strangely hesitant, our momentum lost. We perched on the lip of a tunnel, dangling our feet in the water, using the excuse that we needed a rest.

45452.base_text: There was so much I should be asking him, so much I should be saying, but I couldn’t find a way to start.

variants.text: There was so much I should be asking him, so much I should be saying, but I couldn’t find a way to start.

45452.base_text: Well. I had pretended nothing was wrong for such a long time. Maybe another few minutes wouldn’t hurt.

variants.text: Well. I had pretended nothing was wrong for such a long time. Maybe another few minutes wouldn’t hurt.

45452.base_text: The rippling sounds of the water were peaceful, and I didn’t want to break the silence. But someone had to.

variants.text: The rippling sounds of the water were peaceful, and I didn’t want to break the silence. But someone had to.

45452.base_text: “So.” The sound bounced off vaulted brick, making the chamber even more claustrophobic. I coughed. “We’ve come all this way. We going through, or what?”

variants.text: “So.” The sound bounced off vaulted brick, making the chamber even more claustrophobic. I coughed. “We’ve come all this way. We going through, or what?”

variants.text: “So.” The sound echoed off vaulted brick. I coughed. “We’ve come all this way. We going through, or what?”

45452.base_text: He seemed curiously reluctant, but managed a weak smile. “Sure! Yeah. Let’s do it.”

variants.text: He seemed curiously reluctant, but managed a weak smile. “Sure! Yeah. Let’s do it.”

45452.base_text: We waded over to the hatchway. The wheel was inches under the surface of the water. I pulled the key from my pocket and slipped it into the lock, and it went in smoothly. I spun it through a full turn till it made a tiny chunk, then turned the wheel. After a few revolutions, something gave, and we found we could swing the circular hatch open along one hinged side.

45452.base_text: The words seemed to shake him out of a daze, and he perked up, flashing a huge grin. “Hell yeah! Let’s do it. Let’s go home.”

45452.base_text: We held our glowsticks underwater near the opening. The hatch opened into an ordinary-looking but flooded room beneath us with a yellow-tiled floor. Chrome and porcelain rippled up at us. We realized after a moment it was a flooded bathroom.

45452.base_text: “Huh.” I looked over; he was staring uneasily into the flooded opening. He caught me looking and forced a smile. “Why not, right? Makes as much sense as anything else.” But his gaze slipped off me and up to the vaulted ceiling, like he was interested in the architecture. He wasn’t.

45452.base_text: He was worried about something.

I turned away, ignoring the upwelling of unease, and frowned at the hatch. There was something familiar inside it. I squinted, trying to make the wavering underwater shapes resolve. Tied to something just under the hatchway was a climbing rope, the same kind we’d used with our Grip Monkeys. It stretched down in a taut line out of sight, towards the hidden wall of the room beneath us.

45452.base_text: “What are you doing?” I asked, unsettled.

45452.base_text: He nodded, still not looking at me. “What my evil twin was looking for. The way back through. And if we’re lucky, our doubles will be waiting on the other side. Just like this. Getting ready to swap places, swim through. Get everyone back where they belong, all neat and tidy.”

45452.base_text: “No time like the present,” he said. “Might as well get it over with. Come on in, the water’s fine.”

45452.base_text: “And, uh. You know this how?” I swallowed. Here was the discussion I’d been too afraid to start, happening anyway.

45452.base_text: Something was wrong again. The dark circle of the submerged porthole was ominous. Unknown. This was happening way too fast. “I don’t know. Shit. What if something happens down there? It felt like riding a bike that kept slipping gears, nothing quite fitting together, accelerating down a hill with less and less control, no way to stop.

It felt like riding a bike that kept slipping gears, nothing quite fitting together, accelerating down a hill with less and less control, no way to stop.

45452.base_text: He tensed, frowning at his submerged shoes. “I don’t know it. But we might as well believe it, because if they’re not there, and there’s no more synchronicity between us at all any more? Then who the fuck knows where this rope leads.” He shook his head. “No. They’re over there. We have to believe that. They’re having this same discussion, right now.”

45452.base_text: “They.”

“How did you even know this was here?” My throat tightened. His eyes widened. “No. I can’t do this again. Why won’t any of you be honest with me? Stop it. I know. I know. You’re not… you’re not really…”

45452.base_text: My voice broke and he looked up startled, guilty, afraid. Like a texting jaywalker realizing too late he’s wandered into traffic.

45452.base_text: Somewhere far below us, something groaned, low, immense. The ground quivered, like a mountain turning over in its sleep, and the surface of the water pinched and jittered in sympathy. And just as this happened Niko reached up, eyes wide, and touched two fingers to my lips. Made a zipping motion across them. I was shocked into silence by it all: the sound, the absurdity of the gesture, his fingers on my lips. The fear on his face.

45452.base_text: “Niko,” I said, trembling. “Are you sure you’re… I mean, when we got separated…”

45452.base_text: “Don’t,” he said, quiet. “Please.”

Somewhere far below us, something groaned, low, immense. The ground quivered, like a mountain turning over in its sleep, and the surface of the water pinched and jittered in sympathy. We both dropped half into a crouch, but the earthquake stopped, the low rumbles far beneath us faded. The water we stood in sloshed drunkenly.

What I’d always wanted made real, at last.

45452.base_text: I tried to see him. Really see him. I willed the layers of muck and confusion between us to pull back, to clear away and reveal someone, at last, who I could understand. The Niko who forgave me. The Niko I’d hurt. The Nikos I’d saved, damned, slept with; the ones who needed me, who hated me, who wanted me dead. The one I’d tried so hard to find, looked everywhere for, down here, up there, inside us both and beyond possibility. Each of them were tales disguised as truths; worlds that I yearned to slip into like tailored gloves, sized just right; stories reassuring me that I finally understood what I deserved, good or bad, where I belonged and who I belonged to, and who belonged to me, where I didn’t have to be afraid that I’d love the wrong person or the wrong person would love me.

45452.base_text: “No.” I shook my head. “This can’t be what happens, it’s not right, it’s not fair, it can’t end like this…” Something was slipping from my grasp. I tried to hold on to all the stories I’d told myself about Niko, about me; all the endings I’d wanted for us. Each of them were tales disguised as truths; worlds that I yearned to slip into like tailored gloves, sized just right; stories reassuring me that I finally understood what I deserved, good or bad, where I belonged and who I belonged to, and who belonged to me, where I didn’t have to be alone in a dark bedroom any more with no one who loved me to tuck me in, too afraid to fall asleep.

But maybe not. You think it’s coincidence that every cockeyed theory we’ve had about this place has turned out right? I don’t. If it’s feeding off us, multiplying us, then we’re the prime factor. The base case. You think that if we see the truth, we’ll be destroyed. Well, fuck that. I reject it. I reject it with every ounce of my goddamn being.”

45452.base_text: “Sure.” I took the bag. “I suppose I shouldn’t read it until—?” A faint judder rippled through the ground; for an instant the water danced in interference patterns.

45452.base_text: Awkward. But sort of perfect for the mismatched shape of us, which was, if nothing else, our own.

variants.text: Awkward. But sort of perfect for the mismatched shape of us, which was, if nothing else, our own.

45452.base_text: He looked pained. “Please, please don’t.” Glancing around, he took a deep breath. “Okay. You ready?”

variants.text: He looked pained. “Please, please don’t.” Glancing around, he took a deep breath. “Okay. You ready?”

45452.base_text: I wasn’t, so I stepped forward and hugged him, fierce as the roiling lump in my throat.

variants.text: I wasn’t, so I stepped forward and hugged him, fierce as the roiling lump in my throat.

45452.base_text: “Last one back to the right dimension buys the drinks,” I said, then took one last huge breath and dove headfirst into the hatch.

variants.text: “Last one back to the right dimension buys the drinks,” I said, then took one last huge breath and dove headfirst into the hatch.

45452.base_text: It was nice, but his curls were tickling my nose, and I pulled back before I meant to, reflecting his surprise at this with embarrassment. For a second it looked like he thought I was going to kiss him, and then I thought maybe he was thinking of kissing me, and we both stood uncertain for a second or two before dropping arms and stepping back.

45452.base_text: The thought of swimming into that hole without knowing the way to the other side stabbed a different part of me, the one concerned with oxygen and continued existence. I pushed the fear down but it kept manufacturing images for me: jeans snagging on hidden nails that held me back while I flailed uselessly; huge dead fish swimming the flooded halls with flaking gray skin, bulging eyes growing larger and larger as they closed on me. I imagined drowning. Breathing water instead of air. Spasms of lungs. Knowing you were about to die, only not soon enough. Not nearly soon enough.

45452.base_text: “Are you going to be okay?” he asked.

variants.text: “Are you going to be okay?” he asked.

45452.base_text: “Are you going to be okay?” he asked, without spite this time.

variants.text: “Are you going to be okay?” he asked, without spite this time.

45452.base_text: I didn’t know how to answer, because despite these tidy revelations, the thought of never seeing him again still stabbed at something deep inside me, and maybe always would; and the idea that anyone in this or any world would ever know me as well as he did seemed impossible. But I nodded. Eventually, maybe, it would be true.

But I nodded. Eventually, maybe, it would be true.

45452.base_text: I stared at the circular opening, visualized the motions I’d make. I tried to believe I could do this. I tried to push down the sliver of doubt lodged somewhere in my throat.

variants.text: I stared at the circular opening, visualized the motions I’d make. I tried to believe I could do this. I tried to push down the sliver of doubt lodged somewhere in my throat.

45452.base_text: “How about you?”
Gripping the sides of the hatch, I paused. I wasn’t ready. But if I waited any longer, I’d never be.

variants.text: Gripping the sides of the hatch, I paused. I wasn’t ready. But if I waited any longer, I’d never be.

45452.base_text: He grinned. “I don’t plan to spend a couple decades sulking down here like that asshole, if that’s what you mean.” He looked up at the arched roof above us, scanning the bricks like there might be constellations in them. “I’ve never known what I wanted, man. Just what everybody else wants me to want. I’m sorry I mixed you up in all that.” He shrugged. “Guess I should figure that out, yeah? Spend some time with myself. Maybe more solo camping, you know? Wandering in the wilderness. Worked for Jesus.”

Wandering in the wilderness. Worked for Jesus.”

45452.base_text: “Sure,” I said. “You see that wolf again up there, man… you fucking wreck it.”

variants.text: “Sure,” I said. “You see that wolf again up there, man… you fucking wreck it.”

45452.base_text: We grinned at each other, one last time, or maybe for the first time, depending on how you looked at it: and then I turned away, toward the submerged portal, the way out, the way home. I stared down at it.

variants.text: We grinned at each other, one last time, or maybe for the first time, depending on how you looked at it: and then I turned away, toward the submerged portal, the way out, the way home. I stared down at it.

45452.base_text: I took a deep breath, then another. I tried to slow my heartbeat. I didn’t look at Niko.

variants.text: I took a deep breath, then another. I tried to slow my heartbeat. I didn’t look at Niko.

45452.base_text: Another breath. Breathe. Deeper and deeper.
“Later, skater,” I said, not looking back, then took one last huge breath and dove headfirst into the hatch.

variants.text: “Later, skater,” I said, not looking back, then took one last huge breath and dove headfirst into the hatch.

45453.base_text: I woke up from a dreamless sleep to face the unpleasant truth that we couldn’t stay here forever.

variants.text: I woke up from a dreamless sleep to face the unpleasant truth that we couldn’t stay here forever.

45453.base_text: Hunger woke me, finally rising to the top of my list of needs.

variants.text: Hunger woke me, finally rising to the top of my list of needs.

45453.base_text: Getting back on top of the cylinder had been a problem of broken physics. We couldn’t just climb back up, because there was nothing heavy enough to grip. Maybe a master climber could have started from the bottom of a giant tube of carpet and made his way to the top, but even for Niko climbing had only ever been a fleeting hobby.

variants.text: Getting back on top of the cylinder had been a problem of broken physics. We couldn’t just climb back up, because there was nothing heavy enough to grip. Maybe a master climber could have started from the bottom of a giant tube of carpet and made his way to the top, but even for Niko climbing had only ever been a fleeting hobby.

45453.base_text: With Niko’s help I’d made it back to the top of the suspended bedroom set, as exhausted as I’d ever been. I thought nothing in the world had ever felt so good as lying on my back on a floor, every muscle gloriously unclenched. Wedged in between two dressers, so as not to roll off the edge, we slept.

variants.text: With Niko’s help I’d made it back to the top of the suspended bedroom set, as exhausted as I’d ever been. 45453.base_text: Getting back on top of the cylinder had been like navigating an especially surreal and challenging climbing gym. From his perch on the bookshelf, Niko had scoped out a route from one piece of furniture to the next, and then, in what would have been the most viral parkour video ever if YouTube had been invented yet, leapt from one to the other, till gasping, he scrabbled up to the top of the tube. From there he could pull me up; all I had to do with my shredded muscles was keep hanging on, although that was hard enough. Once we’d made it, I thought nothing in the world had ever felt so good as lying on my back on a floor, every muscle gloriously unclenched.

His idea.

I’d managed to pull myself up to the top of the rope on the last of my shredded muscles and shove my arms into the gap between the bed and the floor, dangling by my armpits. Niko, farther up, worked out a plan. I wasn’t too coherent, but I gather he’d scoped out a route from one piece of furniture to the next, and then, in what would have been the most viral parkour video ever if YouTube had been invented yet, leapt from one to the other, pushing off each one as his weight lifted it off the ground, till gasping, he scrabbled up to the top of the tube.

45453.base_text: When we woke we ate power bars from Niko’s pack: my own had gotten lost somewhere in the fight, probably kicked off and down into the darkness below. I had no idea where to go from here, but Elder Niko’s plan still seemed sound: get across to a hallway on the other side. On the opposite wall of pink foam from the one we’d entered from, what seemed like ages ago, only one open hall was in reach of our floating set. It took some careful grapple work with our tired muscles, but in the end we managed to traverse over to the hallway, relieved to be standing on solid ground once again.

45453.base_text: When we woke we ate power bars from Niko’s pack: my own had gotten lost somewhere in the fight, probably kicked off and down into the darkness below. I had no idea where to go from here, but Niko had noticed something while scrambling around up top. One of the guy-wires sloping down into darkness had loops of rope tied to it every couple of feet, sized just right to be handholds. You could swing from one to the other, like monkey bars, working your way along and underneath. Unlike the guy-wires themselves which were coated in ages of grime, the loops of rope were clean. They looked like recent additions.

45453.base_text: From there it was simply a matter of making an anchor of a stack of fallen books, and flinging it around the tube to make a circular guide rope.

variants.text: From there it was simply a matter of making an anchor of a stack of fallen books, and flinging it around the tube to make a circular guide rope.

45453.base_text: This hallway had a floor of concrete, and was wider. A trench of water ran down its center, spilling out into the canyon behind us and cascading down.

variants.text: This hallway had a floor of concrete, and was wider. A trench of water ran down its center, spilling out into the canyon behind us and cascading down.

45453.base_text: From there it was simply a matter of detaching the chandelier net from its anchor point at the base of the hallway floating above us.

variants.text: From there it was simply a matter of detaching the chandelier net from its anchor point at the base of the hallway floating above us.

45453.base_text: A night’s rest had knitted our muscles back together enough to make the traversal merely painful rather than fatal. Grunting and moaning like old men, we swung away from the set into darkness, hand over hand.

variants.text: A night’s rest had knitted our muscles back together enough to make the traversal merely painful rather than fatal. Grunting and moaning like old men, we swung away from the set into darkness, hand over hand.

45453.base_text: Wedged in between two dressers, so as not to roll off the edge, we slept.

variants.text: Wedged in between two dressers, so as not to roll off the edge, we slept.

45453.base_text: I had to rest for a while before I felt confident enough to make the climb around. But it was only thirty feet, and only a small part of that vertical. Before I could overthink it I’d done it and was back on top. I thought nothing in the world had ever felt so good as lying on my back on a floor, every muscle gloriously unclenched.

45453.base_text: I never would have thought of this. But Niko figured all those glass baubles together ought to weigh more than we did. That the chandelier-web, part of the Confusion, should follow its own gravitational rules, not the ones that dragged us downwards. Like a cloth thrown over a crystal ball, the detached net would wrap around the curvature of the bedroom tube, with both of us inside but not heavy enough to pull it free. We’d be able to crawl back around to the top, ants between the cloth and the glass.

45453.base_text: Before long our headlamps picked out a looming shape ahead: a huge concrete tube snaking horizontal through the blackness and cutting across our path on a diagonal. The wire ran just above it, so when we reached it we could simply step down onto its curving top side to shake out our weary arms.

The wire ran just above it, so when we reached it we could simply step down onto its curving top side to shake out our weary arms.

45453.base_text: When we woke we ate power bars from Niko’s pack: my own had gotten lost somewhere in the fight, probably sliding off the curve and down into the darkness below. I had no idea where to go from here—although it seemed like there were only two options, one way down the tube or the other—but Niko had found a better option while he’d been scrambling around up top. Directly under the invisible anchor point of the densest part of the web, the chandelier itself, was a trapdoor. It opened downward with a creak when you pushed on it, releasing fold-up stairs like the ones that sometimes climb into attics. The stairs descended some fifteen feet to a cement floor bisecting the cylinder. Its upper half was a domed tunnel, vanishing into the distance in either direction. Bare bulbs hung from the roof every fifty feet or so, leaking dim puddles of yellow-orange glow. Water ran down the center in a foot-deep trench, fast enough to gurgle.

45453.base_text: It worked. There must have been some complicated gymnastics up there, and I’m fuzzy on how he got the net loose—maybe he had his own serrated knife—but it worked. Back on top, the net of glass now a glittering ceiling over the bedroom furniture like the world’s most fabulous couch fort, I thought nothing in the world had ever felt so good as lying on my back on a floor, every muscle gloriously unclenched.

45453.base_text: We kept to the level ground on either side of the trench, and started trudging.

variants.text: We kept to the level ground on either side of the trench, and started trudging.

45453.base_text: Niko thought we should head upstream, follow the water toward its source. Too worn down to argue, I agreed.

variants.text: Niko thought we should head upstream, follow the water toward its source. Too worn down to argue, I agreed.

45453.base_text: We moved slowly. Niko had cleaned up the cut in my lower leg as best he could, bandaging it with some socks from a dresser drawer and a tight-wrapped bungee cord from his pack. But it hurt, a lot. I hobbled more than walked, had to stop for frequent breaks, or lean on him for support. He helped me without comment, when I needed it.

45453.base_text: Unsaid things festered between us.

There were no side doors, no junctions, no rooms. There were no decisions to make. We just walked. Other than an occasional grunt or word of coordination, we didn’t speak. A small part of me wanted to ask a million questions. Another part didn’t want the answers. There was a tautness between us, a strain, like a handshake stripped down to bone and gristle, rubbing, raw. I realized maybe it had been there a long time, underneath everything we’d wrapped around it.

45453.base_text: The tunnel had no perceptible slope, but the water in the trench ran fast, rushing eagerly past us. The path stayed straight at first but then began to curve gently leftward. We walked for what felt like a long time.

45453.base_text: The tunnel had no perceptible slope, but the water in the trench ran fast, rushing eagerly past us. The path curved gently left, then gently right. We walked for what felt like a long time.

variants.text: The tunnel had no perceptible slope, but the water in the trench ran fast, rushing eagerly past us. The path curved gently left, then gently right. We walked for what felt like a long time.

45453.base_text: Gradually, the perfect curve of the ceiling began to straighten. The roof above flattened, the curves at its edge sharpening, until they squared off entirely. At the same time the tunnel gradually shrunk back to house-sized dimensions. Presently we were walking down a rectangular hall of concrete, like some forgotten subbasement in a shuttered factory. It felt like we were back “inside” again. The sensation of walking through a pipe suspended over empty space receded, and we felt once again embedded in earth.

There was a tautness between us, a strain, like a handshake stripped down to bone and gristle, rubbing, raw. I realized maybe it had been there a long time, underneath everything we’d wrapped around it.

It was a squat and vaulted brick antechamber, maybe twelve feet across and hexagonal, with tunnels coming in from all six sides. Each seemed identical to the one we’d entered from. Water flooded the sunken floor of the chamber and ran out the trenches in the middle of each tunnel.

45453.base_text: In the center of the room, under the water, was a stubby concrete pillar topped by a metal hatchway with a wheel, like something you’d see on a submarine.

45453.base_text: Once we confirmed it did, we became strangely hesitant, our momentum lost. We perched on the lip of a tunnel, dangling our feet in the water, using the excuse that we needed a rest.

45453.base_text: There was so much I should be asking him, so much I should be saying, but I couldn’t find a way to start.

variants.text: There was so much I should be asking him, so much I should be saying, but I couldn’t find a way to start.

45453.base_text: Well. I had pretended nothing was wrong for such a long time. Maybe another few minutes wouldn’t hurt.

variants.text: Well. I had pretended nothing was wrong for such a long time. Maybe another few minutes wouldn’t hurt.

45453.base_text: The rippling sounds of the water were peaceful, and I didn’t want to break the silence. But someone had to.

variants.text: The rippling sounds of the water were peaceful, and I didn’t want to break the silence. But someone had to.

45453.base_text: “So.” The sound bounced off vaulted brick, making the chamber even more claustrophobic. I coughed. “We’ve come all this way. We going through, or what?”

variants.text: “So.” The sound bounced off vaulted brick, making the chamber even more claustrophobic. I coughed. “We’ve come all this way. We going through, or what?”

45453.base_text: “So.” The sound echoed off vaulted brick. I coughed. “We’ve come all this way. We going through, or what?”

variants.text: “So.” The sound echoed off vaulted brick. I coughed. “We’ve come all this way. We going through, or what?”

45453.base_text: He seemed curiously reluctant, but managed a weak smile. “Sure! Yeah. Let’s do it.”

variants.text: He seemed curiously reluctant, but managed a weak smile. “Sure! Yeah. Let’s do it.”

45453.base_text: We waded over to the hatchway. The wheel was inches under the surface of the water. I pulled the key from my pocket and slipped it into the lock, and it went in smoothly. I spun it through a full turn till it made a tiny chunk, then turned the wheel. After a few revolutions, something gave, and we found we could swing the circular hatch open along one hinged side.

45453.base_text: The words seemed to shake him out of a daze, and he perked up, flashing a huge grin. “Hell yeah! Let’s do it. Let’s go home.”

variants.text: The words seemed to shake him out of a daze, and he perked up, flashing a huge grin. “Hell yeah! Let’s do it. Let’s go home.”

45453.base_text: We held our glowsticks underwater near the opening. The hatch opened into an ordinary-looking but flooded room beneath us with a yellow-tiled floor. Chrome and porcelain rippled up at us. We realized after a moment it was a flooded bathroom.

variants.text: “If this portal thing leads through a toilet,” Niko said, “I’m out.”

45453.base_text: We could only assume the way through was somewhere out of sight, around a corner or down an unseen hall. But how far?

45453.base_text: “The other guys are probably doing the same thing on their side,” I said hopefully. “Maybe we’ll swim through at exactly the same time, go past each other.”

45453.base_text: “Huh.” I looked over; he was staring uneasily into the flooded opening. He caught me looking and forced a smile. “Why not, right? Makes as much sense as anything else.” But his gaze slipped off me and up to the vaulted ceiling, like he was interested in the architecture. He wasn’t.

45453.base_text: “You really think we’re still in sync? After everything that’s happened? Our doubles defeated their own evil Niko with exactly the same strategy and ended up here at precisely the same time as us?”

45453.base_text: He was worried about something.

I turned away, ignoring the upwelling of unease, and frowned at the hatch. There was something familiar inside it. I squinted, trying to make the wavering underwater shapes resolve. Tied to something just under the hatchway was a climbing rope, the same kind we’d used with our Grip Monkeys. It stretched down in a taut line out of sight, towards the hidden wall of the room beneath us.

45453.base_text: “What are you doing?” I asked, unsettled.

45453.base_text: He nodded, still not looking at me. “What my evil twin was looking for. The way back through. And if we’re lucky, our doubles will be waiting on the other side. Just like this. Getting ready to swap places, swim through. Get everyone back where they belong, all neat and tidy.”

45453.base_text: “No time like the present,” he said. “Might as well get it over with. Come on in, the water’s fine.”

variants.text: “No time like the present,” he said. “Might as well get it over with. Come on in, the water’s fine.”

45453.base_text: “And, uh. You know this how?” I swallowed. Here was the discussion I’d been too afraid to start, happening anyway.

45453.base_text: Something was wrong again. The dark circle of the submerged porthole was ominous. Unknown. This was happening way too fast. “I don’t know. Shit. What if something happens down there? What if one of us gets stuck, or needs help? We could fucking drown.” My mind was racing. It felt like riding a bike that kept slipping gears, nothing quite fitting together, accelerating down a hill with less and less control, no way to stop.

Then who the fuck knows where this rope leads.” He shook his head. “No. They’re over there. We have to believe that. They’re having this same discussion, right now.”

45453.base_text: “Let’s just do it,” Niko said brightly. “I mean, the sooner we go through, the sooner we’ll be home.”

45453.base_text: “They.”

“How did you even know this was here?” My throat tightened. His eyes widened. “No. I can’t do this again. Why won’t any of you be honest with me? Stop it. I know. I know. You’re not… you’re not really…”

45453.base_text: My voice broke and he looked up startled, guilty, afraid. Like a texting jaywalker realizing too late he’s wandered into traffic.

45453.base_text: Somewhere far below us, something groaned, low, immense. The ground quivered, like a mountain turning over in its sleep, and the surface of the water pinched and jittered in sympathy. And just as this happened Niko reached up, eyes wide, and touched two fingers to my lips. Made a zipping motion across them. I was shocked into silence by it all: the sound, the absurdity of the gesture, his fingers on my lips. The fear on his face.

Somewhere far below us, something groaned, low, immense. The ground quivered, like a mountain turning over in its sleep, and the surface of the water pinched and jittered in sympathy. We both dropped half into a crouch, but the earthquake stopped, the low rumbles far beneath us faded. The water we stood in sloshed drunkenly.

45453.base_text: The ground groaned again beneath us, more dangerous this time. A brick fell from somewhere above, made a splash loud enough to make us both flinch. But we didn’t break eye contact.

45453.base_text: “But the other Niko,” I gasped, shaking my head, “he’s—”

variants.text: “But the other Niko,” I gasped, shaking my head, “he’s—”

45453.base_text: “Don’t say it,” he breathed.

The ground dropped out from under us, like a plane hitting turbulence. Rumbles quivered in stone far below. I tripped and plunged into water up to my neck as the earth swayed, groaned like a buried titan coming back to life.

45453.base_text: Niko grabbed my arm and pulled me up, put his other on my shoulder, pulled me against him and shouted in my face: “Shut up! Shut up, you fucking idiot, stop talking, stop overthinking everything and just swim through the goddamned tunnel, just swim the fuck through, it’s the only way you’re going to—” And he cut himself off, biting his lip, his eyes filling up with tears.

45453.base_text: Synchronicity.
And then I got it.
I felt like we were balanced on an impossibly heavy pivot, a mountain peak turned upside down. If we leaned too far in any direction…

variants.text: I felt like we were balanced on an impossibly heavy pivot, a mountain peak turned upside down. If we leaned too far in any direction…

45453.base_text: “No,” I said. “I’m not leaving you.”
The air around us held its breath. Where the water touched my knees, it thrummed.

variants.text: The air around us held its breath. Where the water touched my knees, it thrummed.

45453.base_text: Two soap bubbles, pressed together, floating in a vast empty void. Trembling.

variants.text: Two soap bubbles, pressed together, floating in a vast empty void. Trembling.

45453.base_text: “You can’t stay here,” he said, shaking his head. “You know why you can’t.”

variants.text: “You can’t stay here,” he said, shaking his head. “You know why you can’t.”

45453.base_text: Somehow we were closer than we’d been a moment before. The curves of his jaw, his cheek, were aches inside me, blood-memorized, bone-familiar.

45453.base_text: “I can live with pain,” I said, stepping toward him; but he recoiled, and I couldn’t bear to see him do that, wanted more than anything to make him understand: “No, it’s okay. They’re just headaches. The pain doesn’t matter. It’d be worth it. You’re worth it.”

45453.base_text: His lips were too close to mine. It would be so easy. It would last forever, like dying winter sunlight slanting into a room through melting icicles, lighting it up, setting fire to the neurons that had always struggled to keep truths and fictions apart and burning them away forever, every universe fading away like stage lights until the spotlight of that kiss would be the only thing left. What I’d always wanted made real, at last.

45453.base_text: “I want to,” I breathed.
He let go of me, took a step back, face reddening. “I just think,” he said quietly, miserable, “that you should go first, okay?”

45453.base_text: A sharp crack sounded from the wall behind him, but I refused to look away from his eyes, even though all I saw reflected there was my own pain, bitter and jagged.
